relationships.notes: Herod Antipas imprisons John for condemning his marriage to Herodias and ultimately has him beheaded after the banquet oath, making him the ruler responsible for silencing the prophet.
Luke depicts Antipas both as the threat from whom Jesus refuses to flee and as the tetrarch who questions Jesus during the passion, mocks him when no sign is performed, and sends him back to Pilate.

Pilate refers Jesus to Antipas as the Galilean’s rightful tetrarch, and after sharing responsibility for the interrogation they become friends, highlighting cooperation among Roman-aligned rulers during Jesus’s trial.

traits.tetrarchal_role: Presented simply as Herod, ruler under whom John the Baptist’s ministry and death take place.
traits.relationship_to_john_the_baptist: Has John arrested and imprisoned because of John’s criticism of his marriage to Herodias, his brother’s wife.
traits.execution_of_john: Reluctantly orders John’s beheading after Herodias’s daughter’s dance and rash oath, becoming complicit in the prophet’s death.
traits.reaction_to_jesus: Hears of Jesus’s activity and supposes that John whom he beheaded has been raised, indicating a guilty conscience and confusion about Jesus’s identity.

traits.political_status: Identified as Herod the tetrarch, ruling Galilee during the events surrounding John and Jesus.
traits.fear_of_john: Initially wants to put John to death but fears the crowd because they regard him as a prophet.
traits.beheading_of_john: Ultimately orders John’s execution at Herodias’s instigation and because of an oath sworn at his birthday banquet.
traits.interpretation_of_jesus: When he hears about Jesus, declares that John has been raised from the dead, framing Jesus’s miracles as the work of a resurrected John.

traits.tetrarch_of_galilee: Named as tetrarch of Galilee in Luke’s chronological introduction to John the Baptist’s ministry.
traits.opinion_about_jesus: Perplexed by reports about Jesus, wondering whether he is John raised from the dead, Elijah, or another prophet.
traits.mockery_of_jesus: During the passion, questions Jesus at some length, hopes to see a sign, and when Jesus remains silent, mocks him with his soldiers and sends him back to Pilate in a gorgeous robe.
traits.political_function: Luke notes that on that day Herod and Pilate became friends, suggesting that their shared handling of Jesus had political consequences.
